modules.title: I/O System, Device Management, File System, Disk Scheduling

summary: Operating Systems is a comprehensive course designed to build strong foundational knowledge in this important area. This subject covers 6 key modules that progressively develop your understanding. You'll gain both theoretical insights and practical skills through lectures and assignments. The course prepares you for advanced studies and professional applications. Mastering this subject will significantly contribute to your academic and career success.
recommended_books: Operating System Concepts Essentials – Silberschatz, Galvin, Gagne
Operating Systems: Internals and Design Principles – William Stallings
Operating Systems: A Design-Oriented Approach – Charles Crowley
Operating Systems: A Modern Perspective – Gary J. Nutt
Design of the Unix Operating System – Maurice Bach
Understanding the Linux Kernel – Bovet & Cesati
course_outcomes: Define role of Operating System and explain OS design and control units.
Analyze CPU scheduling, synchronization and deadlock handling.
Explain paging, segmentation and virtual memory concepts.
Explain protection and security and compare UNIX and Windows OS.
Understand I/O systems, device management and disk scheduling algorithms.
prerequisites: Basic programming logic, Data Structure & Algorithm concepts, Basic mathematics and digital electronics
